ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
FOREIGN WORKERS
(Training)


    1. Ms Olivia Lum Ooi Lin asked the Minister for Manpower in view of the recent announcement to increase with effect from January 2004 the monthly levy on a single-skilled worker from $30 to

Column: 149

$320 in an effort to encourage construction companies to upgrade the skills of their workers, whether there are any specific interim measures the Ministry will take to help facilitate and ease the burden of construction companies in retraining their workers.

    The Minister for Manpower (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, the construction industry is the largest employer of foreign workers in Singapore. Although the vast majority possess a trade skill, this has not translated into improvements in Singapore's construction productivity. Thus, the Government had introduced multi-skilling and enhanced the skills criteria for lower foreign worker levy. This is to raise the overall skill level of the foreign construction workforce and reduce the industry's reliance on low-skilled workers. Multi-skilled workers can be deployed for a wider range of jobs at a construction site. This will result in more efficient manpower utilisation and higher productivity.

    Sir, my Ministry and the BCA are mindful of the impact the changes may have on the industry. Only new foreign workers recruited after 1st January 2004 have to meet the new skills criteria to be eligible for the lower levy. Existing workers have a transition period of two years until 1st January 2005 to re-qualify for the lower levy. They will continue to be eligible for the low levy (currently at $30 per month) until this date, ie, 1st January 2005. So, most ongoing contracts would not be affected. With the long transition period, contractors would also have sufficient time to adjust their operations and factor the changes in their tenders. They should also have sufficient lead-time to train their workers to acquire a second skill during this period. Contracts of a longer duration that could be severely affected will be considered on a case-by-case basis by BCA.

    Following these changes, contractors should not continue to recruit low skill foreign construction workers. The sensible thing is to make greater efforts to recruit better-skilled and more experienced workers. Business-wise, this is

Column: 150

better than recruiting low-skilled workers to be trained in Singapore. While such multi-skilled workers will expect higher wages, the lower levy and productivity gains will more than offset any higher wage cost.

    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang (Aljunied): Sir, in view of this change, will the Ministry continue to reduce the Man Year Entitlement (MYE) as recommended by the Construction 21 Committee every year?

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is yes. Over the longer term, we will still move towards tightening the allocation of non-traditional source workers under the Man Year Entitlement scheme to contractors. But in view of the slew of changes that has been introduced this year, we have decided that, for this year, we will suspend any further revision of the Man Year Entitlement scheme. But, starting from next year, we will review the situation and if, in fact, there is still room for further reduction, which we believe that there would be, then we will carry on to achieve the target set by Construction 21, which is to half the dependency on foreign construction workers within a certain timeframe or faster, if we can achieve it.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [28th February, 2003].

    Question again proposed.



    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to start this important and landmark Budget Debate for FY 2003.

    This year's Budget is different from the norm in the past years. It contains Government's strategies and plans over the longer term based on its response and general acceptance of the Economic Review Committee's Report. At the same time, as a standard practice, the Budget Statement spelt out the Government's immediate fiscal and monetary plans, tax changes and action plans for the new financial year. This two-pronged long term and short term discourse of the Government's strategies and plans does require some re-orientation to readers and observers, trying to understand better this year's Budget.

    Along the same vein as the Budget announcement, I shall also structure my comments on this year's Budget into two sections, covering first the ERC Report and then the FY 2003 Budget.

    First, on the ERC Report. This is a monumental exercise involving about

Column: 152

1,000 persons directly involved in sub-committees and working groups over a period of one year. I liken this exercise to 1,000 cooks labouring together to create a Singaporean favourite dish, eg, the char kway teow, with DPM Lee as our chief cook. Now, this dish is cooked and being served to the people. What are the responses and reactions so far? Are the people satisfied? I believe the verdict is, like all recipes, it cannot cater to all tastes. Some like it, some do not. And some do not care! So, not everybody can be fully satisfied. Some want extra hot, some like it sweet. Everybody wants more goodies in it, but no one wants it bitter.

    Many people have said that the final ERC Report is not exciting. Nothing new or phenomenal has resulted from it. There is no grand vision. Where are the bold measures? Generally, no excitement. I have to admit that I tend to share some of these sentiments.

    However, on balance, I wish to point out that the ERC Report has accomplished its mission very well. No one should belittle the profound effort, the numerous valid recommendations and the vital conclusions of the ERC Report. One thousand of the best minds, top managers, businessmen and political leaders had, in great earnestness, reviewed all the major economic and economic-related policies that literally left no stones unturned. It is also correct that those stones that are found to be all right are put back - no need to change for change's sake.

    The involvement of the large number of people has served the purpose of bringing together wider participation of many people in charting the future of Singapore. The Report has been most comprehensive, covering every economic and related issue. I support, in principle, all the recommended policy changes with regard to taxation, CPF, manufacturing and service industries development, human capital and others.

    Mr Speaker Sir, allow me to spell out my specific comments regarding certain recommendations in the ERC Report.

Column: 153



    First, concern on depressing wages and land values. A main thrust that appears to come across strongly in the ERC Report is that, henceforth, the Government wants to keep the factors of production, ie. land, rentals, wages and other operating costs low. This is a well-intended objective. I have no quarrel with that. But I wish to remark that we cannot artificially hold down prices. We do wish to hold down increases in Government rates and fees, wherever possible, but many costs, such as wages, land and rentals, are dictated by the market, and the general affluence of the people. Every year, every employee wants to see an increase in his take-home pay, so as to at least match or better inflation and rising costs of expenses. They want to see improving living standards for themselves and their families. How then can we intentionally hold down prices? Moreover, it is not correct to artificially press down values. Do we not recognise that we cannot compete with our neighbouring countries, especially against China and India based on low production cost?

    I wonder what happened to the previously much promoted policy of going for higher technology and higher value added products, and to promote our brain services sector. Not much has been said in the ERC Report on this aspect. Is it an understood issue or is it deliberately de-emphasised in the Report? If it is intentional, it is useful to explain why.

    Next, concern on deflation. In line with my doubt on the wisdom of focusing on depressing the costs of production, and therefore depressing values, I also have a worry on the underlying deflationary effects of such a policy. It is therefore timely that I read in a report warning about "Overshooting deflation threatens Singapore" in the Business Times on Saturday, 8th March 2003, in a study by the US investment bank, Goldman Sachs.

    In the report, Goldman Sachs forewarned that, in recent years since the Asian financial crisis, there have been a series of negative shocks which add up

Column: 154

to the largest deflationary demand shock the modern Singapore economy has ever faced. Some of the factors cited are :

    (a) 12% deterioration in terms of trade since 1996, ie, after the Asian financial crisis;

    (b) Rise in regional political risk premium and lower direct investment to the region;

    (c) Emergence of competition from China; and

    (9) Restructuring of Government-linked companies involving lay-offs.

    I would add to the above list that there is also the uncertainty in the domestic sector with the recent high profile lay-offs in the Government sector - of PSA Corporation and HDB. So, I am indeed very fearful that if it is the professed intention of the Government to keep wages and land values low, it will further dampen the already depressed mood of the people, leading to lower domestic spending which, in turn, will cause domestic demand to spiral downwards into a deflationary loop. I strongly urge the Government to look into this concern of threat of deflation.

    Next, changing mindset to promote entrepreneurship. Another key thrust of the ERC Report is to promote entrepreneurship, so as to cultivate an entrepreneurial nation. One of the three main tenets of the Report is to remake Singapore into "a creative and entrepreneurial nation willing to take risks to create fresh businesses and blaze new paths to success". I like this principle and I fully support it. However, I feel that this is easier said than done. It requires substantial effort and total commitment from all. Our people and our children are too used to being led, guided and spoon-fed by the Government. We have to break out of the old mould. We need a fundamental mindset change, to be creative and take initiative. But can we?

    Let me quote an observation that shows that we have an arduous task to change

Column: 155

the people's mindset, though we must. Someone called this the No U-Turn Syndrome (or "NUTS", in short). In the US, the general traffic rule is that a driver can do U-turns along any road unless specifically prohibited by No U-turn signs. In Singapore, it is the reverse. Motorists are not allowed to do U-turns unless specifically permitted at locations where permitted signs are shown. That means that they cannot do anything, unless the authorities say "yes". This mindset of NUTS (or No U-Turn Syndrome) is so ingrained in our Singaporean mentality that we do not dare to do anything unless we get a "yes" from the Government. How then can we promote initiative and creativity?

    Let me cite another traffic rule example. In the US, where traffic is right hand drive, motorists are allowed to turn right at all signalised junctions on red light, provided the traffic is clear; and unless there are signs prohibiting this right turning. But, in Singapore, it is again the reverse. We cannot turn left at signalised junctions on red. However, a few years ago, LTA allowed the rule of "Turn Left On Red" or "TLOR" at some minor roads. The shocking thing is that I have seen with my own eyes, motorists who dare not make left turns on red, even though there are signages permitting it, and the traffic is clear! This is the Singaporean mentality.

    I would like to get our people to be more entrepreneurial. I believe the Government, being a caring parent, must learn how to "let go". We should cut down on rules and red tapes. We have to give the people their choices to make. We have to get out of the habit of planning every minuscule matter for our people. Give them more avenues to express themselves.

    Sir, on GST, in view of the budget deficit and the estimated $650 million cost for deferment of 1% GST increase for one year, I support the Government's intention to proceed to implement the second instalment of the next 1% increase in GST in January 2004. It is prudent not to incur higher deficit due to insufficient revenue collections if the GST increase is deferred further.

Column: 156



    On CPF, I agree with the recommendation to defer the restoration of the balance 4% CPF for another two years. This will enable companies to save on lower operating costs and better able to sustain their viability during this depressed business environment. However, I do want to voice my concern for those workers most affected, such as those in the older age group of 50 years old and above. This age group will not have their CPF cut restored, and will have to contribute more to their CPF Special and Medisave accounts. The lowering of the CPF salary ceiling from $6,000 to $5,000 will also mean that they will receive less contribution to their CPF from their employers. Then, they will have to face the double blow of higher expenses due to the further increase in GST totalling 2%, and, of course, general living expense increases which are inevitable. Therefore, the lower income group and the higher age group will continue to need support from the Government in the form of S&CC rebates, rental and utility rebates.

    Sir, on the next step for the ERC. As I said earlier, the ERC Report is very wide and comprehensive. What I find lacking are the specific recommendations on the implementation details to achieve the stated plans. I can concede that it will be too thick to spell out the actual implementation plans for every recommendation. It is, therefore, left to the relevant Ministries and agencies to follow through.

    The Report states that the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) will co-ordinate the follow-through actions. Whilst I do not doubt the capability of MTI to undertake this task, I do wish to voice out aloud why it is not deemed important enough for this matter to be monitored henceforth by the Prime Minister's Office, or the Deputy Prime Minister's Office. I feel that the overseeing body should be either PMO, or by the DPM himself. In any case, he is the Chairman of the ERC.

    This rationale for high level monitoring is similar to the new Ministerial Committee on Services. I fully support the formation of this Ministerial Committee on Services to oversee the development

Column: 157

of major new services, such as health, media and education. The reason is that the work crosses over many Ministries with inter-ministerial issues. Similarly, most of the ERC recommendations cut across Ministries. Therefore, a supra-Ministerial person being in-charge should spur smoother and speedier implementation.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to move on to the policies and measures announced in the Budget for FY 2003. As I have said earlier, the difficulty with this year's Budget debate is that we have to shift our orientation between the long term issues spelt out in the ERC Report, and then re-focus back to the short term matters in the Budget.

    This could be one reason why the reception to the ERC Report has been lukewarm, as some attention of the public has been diverted to short-term impact measures announced in the Budget.

    Sir, on focus on short term issues and threats. We know that the ERC Report is a very important landmark document. It spells out fully the total blueprint for Singapore's future survival. However, the general public is more focused on their immediate problems. Their immediate concerns are unemployment, firstly; then the uncertainty of domestic economic recovery, diminishing asset values, the looming threat of war in Iraq and the fall-outs of war, the unclear US economic recovery, terrorism, threats of China and India, quarrels with our nearest neighbour Malaysia, and the unclear geo-politic development in Indonesia. Looking through this long list, there is indeed reason for our people to feel deeply worried. Many are experiencing a sense of loss and despondency. The road ahead is hazy and directionless.

    Sir, turning back to the Budget for FY 2003, the Budget will see a deficit of $900 million. This is the third year of deficit in a row. It is a cause for concern on Government's principle of budget prudence. We have budget deficit for three years in a row.

Column: 158



    In this context, I can accept the announcement that there will be no corporate and personal income tax cuts and no income tax rebate for FY 2003. To make such cuts now will mean that there will be a larger budget deficit. However, I would urge the Minister for Finance that should good times return next year, please do not forget to reward the hardworking tax-paying people by giving them some income tax rebates.

    On the other hand, if the world and domestic economies remain poor for a few years, I wonder how would the Government meet its stated intention to cut direct taxes to 20% by 2005, without incurring further budget deficits or introducing higher GST increase. The latter move, of course, will be very unpopular.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, although we have a deficit budget for the new year, there is also a disappointment that the new Budget is not stimulative enough for the domestic economy. I do admit that I seem to be speaking with a forked tongue. Just a moment ago, I expressed concerns about a continuing budget deficit, and now I seem to be urging the Government to spend more to create a higher budget deficit to stimulate the economy.

    Let me explain. Although we said that Singapore has incurred three years of deficits, on closer examination, the deficits are still very small. In FY 2001, a total deficit of about $2.8 billion was incurred. This was about 10% of the total Government revenue for that year. This deficit was high but it was needed to stimulate the economy against a recession then. Last year's deficit for FY 2002 has been revised and estimated to be a modest $0.1 billion or $100 million, versus the original figure of $0.9 billion, or $900 million. So, FY 2002 is nearly a balanced budget.

    But for FY 2003, the estimated deficit is $0.9 billion. This is only 3% of the total Government's operating revenue collections for the new year amounting to $29.6 billion. For the sake of getting our economy out of the rut, and to give a booster to the people and business confidence, I would advocate a higher deficit

Column: 159

for this new financial year. I believe we can afford it.

    Generally, it is thought that a deficit budget is expansionary. I would like to point out that this is not necessarily true. It depends, to a major extent, where the budget funds are allocated. If funds are not earmarked for expansionary projects, like infrastructure and growth, but to longer term projects like education and social targets, then a deficit budget may not be expansionary. This year's budget may be in a deficit, but I am not sure whether it is a sufficiently expansionary budget.

    To make matters worse, we understand that the Government has directed Ministries to cut down expenditures on projects and various spending. Would this instruction of the Ministry of Finance be counter-expansionary? We are beginning to hear feedback from the private sector companies that they are receiving fewer contracts from the Government. If this trend were to continue, would it not aggravate an already depressed economy?

    Sir, I would like to ask the Minister for Finance whether this year's Budget is indeed a stimulative budget. What are the measures to kick start the sputtering domestic economy? Where are the engine boosters? We do not have tax cuts, no pump priming was mentioned, and no announcement about additional infrastructure spending. So, how are we going to stimulate the economy to grow?

    Moving on to what I call the "crutch mentality", there is another dichotomy that I wish to raise. This is with regard to the continuation of the use of rebates and welfare benefits to help the lower income group and less privileged to overcome the various higher indirect tax burdens such as GST increase and the higher cost of living expenses. I am afraid that the long term use of rebates, reliefs and benefits will lead to a crutch mentality of the people.

    Somehow, we have to gradually wean the less able segment of the people to take care of themselves and become less

Column: 160

dependent on welfare and financial aid. The same applies to the young. This contention is in line with my previous point that to build a truly entrepreneurial nation, the people have to learn to be less dependent on the Government, before we can truly create a new entrepreneurial and vibrant nation.

    The message must be made clear - the Government will help you today, but you must learn to take care of yourself tomorrow.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we are living in very uncertain times. The sense of despondency is actually worse this year compared to last year. I recall that during the budget debate last year, my Backbench colleagues and I had already warned about this sense of doom and gloom prevailing in Singapore then. With higher unemployment, announcements of layoffs, and fear of the looming war in Iraq, the general sense of despondency is higher today. There is a general sense of haplessness as many factors are totally outside our control.

    We need to boost the confidence of the people. This is a priority task. Our people have to first understand and get used to a future where double digit growth and continuing tax cuts, more NSS and ERS shares will not be easy to come by. We have to re-orientate our expectations of growth. We have to accept that, henceforth, each incremental achievement requires greater effort.

    But, sometimes, I cannot help but have the feeling that we do tend to over-plan in Singapore. I recall that we had in the past the Vision 1999, The Next Lap and, more recently, the Singapore 21 Plan. We also had the Economic Committee in 1985. It seems like deja vu. No wonder there is muted enthusiasm to this ERC Report.

    However, I do wish to commend the Government for launching and completing the Economic Review Committee's Report. The people have been held in suspense, pending the release of the ERC Report. Now that the ERC Report, as well as the Budget, is announced, we should

Column: 161

move on. The Government has laid down the clear long-term goals. The new fiscal and monetary policies have been spelt out. The new directions have been set. It is time to get on with the business.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, whatever is happening around us currently in the world, Singapore has to find its place. We cannot foresee and plan ahead for everything. If we can be nimble and creative, we shall always be able to find our place in this world. The Government must show strong leadership in difficult times. The people must respond and shoulder its share of the burden. Let us put on our hard hats and boots and take up the changkol. Together, let us start ploughing, to re-build a better future for our children as best as we can.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in the debate. Sir, today, I would like to talk on three points. First of all, my assessment of the Budget - what it achieved and what it failed to achieve and what more could have been done. Second, I would like to comment on the implementation of the ERC recommendations and, finally, I will touch on the issue of entrepreneurship and what I feel will be the strategies needed to be successful in this area.

    My assessment of the Budget, as I listened to the Finance Minister delivering it, was that it seemed to be a balanced budget, addressing both the short term and immediate issues as well as the longer term issues needed to address the restructuring of the Singapore economy. As I analysed the Budget further, I actually saw very few new initiatives to make this Budget exciting enough to catch the attention of long-term investors. But before I touch on this point, I would like to square off some very obvious things that, in my opinion, were the disappointments of this Budget.

    First of all, this Budget did not address the concerns of the middle group of Singaporeans. While we did take care of

Column: 162

the lower income Singaporeans through the various rebates, it did nothing to assure the biggest group of Singaporeans who may have more assets than the lower income Singaporeans, but who, in the short term, have the same concerns which worry them and, that is, the loss of jobs and the short-term financial help that they can get from the Government. I feel that the Minister should have done much more to assure Singaporeans that their problems will be addressed in times of difficulties. The Minister should have put in place a temporary scheme to make cash accessible to such Singaporeans, for example, a 1% tax reduction could have helped these people in tough times and these are the people who are paying tax and who may have lost their jobs.

    Sir, the second issue is the budget deficit, in my opinion, is hardly a deficit. It seems to me that the Minister tried very hard to end up with a deficit budget by making huge special transfers in the three areas of ERS, Lifelong Learning Fund and Medical Endowment Fund. Similarly, I do not see how the year 2003 Budget will end up in a deficit. Again, we are making special transfers, and we are forecasting a lower NII and we did not seem to have fully accounted for the 1% GST increase and the special income coming by way of more COEs expected. So if we had spent a bit more in trying to help companies and individuals in difficulties, perhaps that deficit would have been a welcomed deficit.

    So what about the long term cost competitiveness of Singapore? Has the Minister missed out looking at this serious recommendation, made not only by the ERC, but also by the many, many committees before the ERC, like the SME21, the T21 and the Cost Competitiveness Committee? I feel that the Minister again lost the golden opportunity to address once and for all this critical issue that is sinking the Singapore economy. I am really disappointed at the seemingly short-term thinking of the Government, especially on this important area of cost competitiveness. And why do I say short term? The measures like temporary rental rebates, temporary property tax rebates

Column: 163

and temporary CPF cuts do nothing in instilling confidence among longer term investors that, indeed, Singapore will still remain competitive not only two years from now, but also 10 years or 20 years from now. In fact, the current approach just drives investors harder to move out faster while they can, while the rebates are still in place. As a serious investor, I know that I have to worry that in six months, rentals and property tax will go up again and that the CPF will again go up in two years. The thought process will surely be to encourage companies to prepare to move out before costs once again increase when the regime of temporary rebates and temporary increases run out and go back to a steady state of higher costs.

The ideas are all there - differential land pricing, structural changes in the wage system, levies, fees, charges from the Government and utilities, logistics and telecommunication charges. We have enough data to show that Singapore is not competitive in all these areas.

    Second, the issue of implementation of the ERC. We all know that many Singaporeans were involved in the above process of deriving the ERC recommendations. I must admit that there was some skepticism among some people involved in the process and a comment which summed up the feeling went like this:

    "I have been asked to give my feedback many, many times before for so many years. What is the point? The Government does not listen and does not believe in us anyway." Sir, this is a true quote coming from a few prominent Singaporeans. To convince them, the argument that all of us who were involved in this process was that, this time round, the Government has realised that there is a need to change for the survival of Singapore and everyone's input was needed. The outcome has been a lot of hard work by many, and the many recommendations to remake the Singapore economy.

Column: 164



    While on the whole, the recommendations have been bold and will make a big difference, there are certain areas which could have been better dealt with. First, the impression that we have is: are we really re-tuning or refining the economy? We were promised that there were no sacred cows and that no stones will be left unturned in this whole exercise. The outcome in a number of areas, which I felt could have made an even bigger difference, was not changed. The ERC could have exercised greater will power to make bolder changes in certain areas. Unfortunately, the impression many people have is that all we have done is once again to just make tweaks in certain areas when we should have made fundamental changes to turn things around. When the whole exercise started, we talked about the remaking and restructuring of our economy. It now appears more like a refining and re-tuning exercise in certain areas. Yes, we did pick the stones and place them back in the same place or in some other place. We missed the golden opportunity to make much needed changes to the economy.

    Let me back up my argument with a few examples. First of all, the tax system. We have been touting the tax changes as a major structural change, but as far as I can see, there was no real change in the system. The real big change happened when the Government implemented the GST system, I believe, in 1994. The ERC recommendations merely reaffirmed the 1994 changes. So the ERC's recommendation of a reduction of personal and corporate tax rate was long overdue anyway. It should have come down drastically the day we implemented the GST changes. The tax changes, in my opinion, were not radical enough.

    The second example is that of the CPF. It is becoming a habit now to tweak the CPF rate in times of crisis. While I am not against this to help us in the short term, this does not give us comfort that we have gotten to the root cause of the problem and that we are just addressing the symptoms. Is it not sufficiently clear that we have a structural problem with the CPF

Column: 165

system? We should have worked on a more permanent solution, perhaps a lower contribution from employers and compensated by alternated retirement and medical schemes. Had we made bolder changes, we may never have to fiddle with the CPF contributions now and then.

    Sir, the final example is one of land prices, and in this topic, I tend to defer from Mr Leong. I believe that the high cost of property, particularly industrial land, is a big issue. To me, this is one of the most serious structural problems, other than the wage which directly affects Singapore's competitiveness, particularly in areas of manufacturing. So while we may talk about moving low value-added activities outside Singapore and trying to bring in more high-tech and high value-added activities in Singapore, the problem is the image that we have created for ourselves is that we are a place where business activity is going to cost companies a lot of money. It is a high-cost country. And I have personally visited a customer about three weeks ago in the US, trying to bring in what I thought was a high-tech activity into Singapore, and the answer I got from them was "We will probably not be coming into Singapore. But if you can promise to do it in China or some other low-cost countries for me, I will move my high-tech activity there." The problem we suffer is that the image that we have created for ourselves is one of a high-cost country. So we really need to fix this problem once and for all.

    The second issue is on the implementation of the ERC Report's recommendations and roadmap. All of us agreed that the ERC exercise was a key and necessary initiative. But, in my opinion, we reacted a bit too late. There were already a few signals that we could have picked up had we been more attentive. We could have reacted much earlier. The few signals were the bursting of the property bubble in 1996, the Asian financial crisis, the emergence of China and India and the flow of FDIs into China. These are all new things. We could have reacted earlier.

Column: 166



    But anyway, now that we have identified so many initiatives, including some considered taboo in the past, we should now roll up our sleeves and start implementing them quickly, a point that Mr Leong made earlier. The ERC should not end up as an academic exercise. Too many important people have set aside their valuable time to be involved and we cannot risk disappointing them and again failing to implement the recommendations decisively. More importantly, we cannot risk failing the Singapore economy. The reason I am bringing this up is because, in the past, we have undergone similar exercises with the likes of the S21, SME21, Retail 21 and the many '21' initiatives. For some of these exercises, we were big on plans, but short on actions. We risk losing the confidence of the key stakeholders of Singapore, should we fail in the implementation. The number of recommendations is overwhelming and, if not handled well and not implemented systematically, we could lose the intended impact.

    So when I read in the papers recently about Singapore climbing up one notch among the most expensive cities in the world compared to the year before, we actually became more expensive and not less expensive by one notch. My heart sank simply because it goes to show that we have not moved fast enough in our restructuring exercise. The second concern I have is that, in our attempt to restructure, are we doing this in isolation? We should, in fact, be aware of the fact that there is a rapidly changing environment around us. Our neighbours are also contemplating the same thing as us. We are working with a moving target. We want to lower the cost of doing business, so do our neighbours. We want to be the Life Sciences Hub in Singapore, so do cities like Xian, Hyderabad, Bangkok and Kuala Lumpur.

    I cannot over-emphasise the need for speed. I believe it is not only the ideas which will define our success, but more importantly, our ability to implement these ideas and our ability to implement them swiftly which will determine how successful we will be in transforming our

Column: 167

economy. So let us not get too complacent but get moving faster than what we are doing right now.

    An example of a non-starter and a failed attempt which comes to mind is the NatSteel divestment saga, which dragged on for so long. The inability to make a judgement to take a certain amount of loss, has resulted in the sloppy execution, in my opinion, of the NatSteel divestment. It is clear that Temasek failed to realise this to be a short term loss but a long term gain. Because it has to answer to the people of Singapore, it therefore has to err on the safe side by taking a kiasu approach in ensuring the best possible value because they have to answer to all of us. Therefore, this is the cause of Government getting involved in business in the first place. In the process, we lost a greater opportunity of setting an excellent example of a GLC divestment done successfully for the long-term good of the country.

    I would therefore like to see an implementation roadmap and an implementation committee, like what Mr Leong suggested, with the responsibility of ensuring that recommendations are implemented the way we intended them to be, and with the speed necessary to achieve the intended impact.

    It will be good for this implementation committee to share its results regularly by publishing a scorecard for all of us to see.

    Sir, the final topic I would like to touch upon is entrepreneurship. Having been so used to developing a corporate-based economy in the last 30 years, the real question we have to ask is: are we willing and are we ready to make the transformation to an entrepreneurial economy? And I think this is the most difficult question for us to answer.

    There are two key elements for us to succeed. Firstly, understanding what it takes to create an entrepreneurial economy and, secondly, the lessons learnt from our successes with the multi-national companies.

Column: 168



    First of all, understanding what it takes to create an entrepreneurial economy. This is the biggest challenge and the most difficult one to overcome. Unless and until we resolve this issue, we will never be able to transform our economy. The challenge, therefore, for the Government and the Minister for Entrepreneurship is to make a sincere pledge to lead this transformation of our economy and, then, to understand what is needed to make this transformation.

    The first challenge, therefore, is that of a mindset change. Yes, it is difficult to attract foreign companies to invest and set up shop in Singapore, but it is even more difficult for our economic agencies to visualise how a start-up or a non-entity - someone who is trying to do a start-up - can one day evolve into a world-class company based in Singapore. So, it is therefore compelling to still take the relatively easy way out of continuing to deal with a corporate-based economy - the tried and tested model.

    The unfortunate fact is that I feel the Government is still unsure or half-hearted about putting in place an entrepreneurial economy. Why is this so? If we ask anyone of the Government economic agencies or the civil servants who are driving this initiative, we cannot help but conclude that they are still programmed to bring in foreign MNCs. The sad thing is that many are sceptical about the ability of our local entrepreneurs to make it big. I say this from my own personal experience and from direct feedback from would-be entrepreneurs.

    Sir, the second issue on entrepreneurship is lessons learnt from our successes with MNCs. If the mindset change can be achieved, then I feel that the next few steps needed to succeed in transforming our economy and of encouraging more entrepreneurs to set up their bases in Singapore would be much easier. We can learn from our successes in the economic development of Singapore in the first 30 years, which have been in attracting foreign direct investments, multinational companies, and in establishing bigger companies, ie, the Government-linked

Column: 169

companies here. We can then apply them as we focus on building an entrepreneurial economy.

    There are three main lessons to be learned from building a corporate economy. They are, first, creating a conducive environment; second, putting in place incentive schemes; and last, but not least, a hand-holding of multinational companies from cradle to grave. What I am about to say may seem obvious, but I feel that we have not fully understood the root causes and have not addressed and learnt from these lessons, and to address the issues on how we can successfully create our entrepreneurial economy.

    Sir, firstly, on creating a conducive environment for MNCs to set up base, why were we successful? Because the Government had developed an appropriate infrastructure, offered cheap land, removed other obstacles that may have existed and made it easy for MNCs to decide to start up operations here. Rules and regulations were tailor-made for MNCs and for bigger companies. Many of the MNCs and GLCs had direct access to top civil servants and Ministers, and this allowed them to resolve issues faster. The lesson here is that the rules made for bigger companies will not work for start-ups and for smaller companies.

    Secondly, on incentives and financing schemes made for bigger companies. To complement the setting up of a conducive environment, the economic development agencies developed a slew of incentive schemes, Government grants and tax breaks, again tailor-made for MNCs and for bigger companies. The lesson here is that while it is easy for big companies to apply and utilise the incentive schemes, the smaller companies find it terribly difficult to do the same.

    Thirdly, hand-holding of MNCs from cradle to grave. This, in my opinion, is the most significant initiative implemented here that made MNCs most comfortable in setting up bases in Singapore. Kudos to the EDB for this. We created a one-stop

Column: 170

agency which hand-held MNCs coming into Singapore, right from the time that we were courting, through the time that they started operations in Singapore, up to the time that we encouraged them to leave for places like Batam and Suzhou.

    Having dealt with EDB on many occasions - while working in a multi-national company as well as when I went to start up my own local companies - I thought I had a good feel of how they operate. I must confess that I really understood EDB only after reading its book published recently called Heartwork. It is an excellent book. After reading it, I understood why EDB did what it did, and became even more convinced that EDB will never be able to handle and help local start-ups. I would like to say that the EDB has done an excellent job all these years but, having understood the charter and the mode of operation, especially after reading the book, I realised that it is unfair and impossible for them to effectively support local companies. Let me share one example from the book to illustrate the mindset with which it operated in helping bigger companies coming into Singapore.

    Sir, in the book, what I read was, when Apple computers wanted to set up a factory in Singapore many years ago, EDB went the full mile, did all the work for Apple in fitting up the whole factory. In fact, it went even further than that. An officer was allocated on a full-time basis to become the project manager for setting up of the factory. The American manager who was responsible for setting up the Apple factory in Singapore did not have to be personally here in Singapore while the facilities were being set up. That is what I call service.

    Can anyone in this House give me an example of a similar service for our local companies? I do not know of any. The reality is that most local companies are left on their own to fight their own battles and to clear the many obstacles themselves. At times, I dare say that the bureaucracy works against them. The lesson here is that had we not had EDB to champion the cause of MNCs, we may not have developed such a vibrant economy.

Column: 171

Champion agencies can do wonders because of the influence they have in clearing these obstacles. So, how can we apply these lessons?

    Firstly, let us create a conducive environment by making a review of rules - which is happening, and I think the rules should not just be reviewed but also revamped - this time round, by putting smaller companies and start-ups centre-stage when we develop these rules.

    Secondly, of course, is to revisit all the incentive schemes and tailor them to suit start-ups and SMEs.

    Thirdly, we really need an EDB-style organisation, a one-stop agency for SMEs and start-ups. Today, we see too many agencies claiming to champion the SMEs and entrepreneurs, but my experience with them is such that none is able to provide the comprehensive service that EDB does for MNCs. Many things, in fact, fall into the crack for entrepreneurs and smaller companies. We need a champion.

    Finally, to build a vibrant financing environment, such as the ones that exist in entrepreneurial economies in the USA, Taiwan and Israel. I will elaborate on these during the Committee of Supply debate.

    Sir, in conclusion, the budget is just one of the many levers to address the current situation that we are in. The current crisis is different from the previous predicaments, although we may use the same terminology to describe them. We have been using the same old formula to address these new predicaments. The context of the problem has changed. And it will continue to change, because we live in a world where change is a constant. As a result, each crisis will become more complex than the previous one. We have to adopt newer measures, and the speed of implementation is essential for their success. This year's budget is being hailed as a budget in transition. My opinion is that we need to get out of this transition quickly. We have been in the transition mode for quite some time. We need to arrive at an economic model that we want very quickly. We have been planning for

Column: 172

quite some time. The planning phase is over. It is now time to execute and implement bold measures. We cannot be half-hearted in our endeavours. We need to be clear in thought and be decisive in action.

    Sir, on the belief that the Minister will implement swiftly these new measures, I support this motion.

managed here. When my daughter was learning to ride the bicycle, I gave her trainer wheels first. Then, when she was a little bit more confident, I kinked it up, removed the trainer wheels, held the seat, and then let her go!

    I do not think we need to go through such an arduous process in this philosophical shift. But there is a case to be made for some short-term forms of assistance which will deliver some relief to those who have worked very hard in Singapore over the years, but due to the circumstances shifting quite suddenly in some cases, they are caught in a difficult spot. This may not require a large resource allocation, but perhaps more a tweaking of existing rules in terms of how they can in fact tap their own resources, whether it is through CPF or other means, such as reverse mortgages, and special schemes for them. And I do hope that the Government will consider that seriously in the next year as a means of helping those in this sandwich class.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Sir, last week I was in Shanghai for a seminar to promote listings on the Singapore Stock Exchange. The seminar was held in a modern international 5-star hotel located at the rather fashionable Bund in Shanghai. More than a hundred interested parties attended, each of whom was carefully screened ahead of time to ensure that they are serious and profitable participants. The hall was packed. Those who attended took earnest notes and looked very serious about going overseas to raise their profile and, perhaps, capital. Perhaps, this reflects the strong vibrancy of the increasingly powerful Chinese economy. This was not only evident in the seminar room, but was clearly visible in the streets, shops and eating-places in the city. However, that was not what struck me. What struck me was a conversation I had with a local accountant who was present at the seminar. He told me that the Chinese recognise that they cannot go on competing on cheap labour and land alone. He recognised that in order for China to continue powering away, they

Column: 198

must strive to move up the value chain and build on local brand names that are recognised internationally. Far from just wanting to be the back-lane sweatshops for some other people's inventions, they have strong aspirations to be the Toyotas, IBMs and Panasonics of the world.

    My conversation with the Chinese accountant made me realise how fast and how aggressive the Chinese are in trying to scale the ladder of economic development to become a developed nation, rivalling the US in every aspect. And I shudder to think of what this would all mean to Singapore, its economy and the future of its people.

    The truth of the matter is surely that the gap of comparative advantage that Singapore has over competing and emerging economies is fast eroding. In Singapore, we have always prided ourselves in having a brand name that is instantly recognisable and respected the world over. We can always leverage on this to charge a premium for our products and services. And it is this brand name which I believe that will hold the key to our future survival.

    The way forward for our country is not to take China on in this competition game, but to see how we can lean on our unique qualities of being a well-run, hardworking and honest English-speaking society to ensure our future survival. What do I mean? Sir, please allow me to take a leaf from the humble shoemaker. On a value chain, the common perception is that shoe-making and selling does not quite occupy the same space as bio-medical science or rocket engineering science. Yet, in terms of profitability and size of global reach, there is huge potential in this business. Take Nike, for example. No one would deny that Nike today is a global multinational whose products can be found in almost every nation on earth. Most people would have either heard of the brand or even own a pair of Nike. There are many people out there, including many young boys and girls who would give a limb for a pair of Nike. They are not able to own it because a pair of Nike shoes is just too expensive for many.

Column: 199

And those who can afford it will not think twice about paying premium money for it. Yet, we know that Nike outsources the manufacturing of its shoes to the sweatshops in China, Vietnam and Indonesia. The factories that churn out these shoes for Nike have the capability of producing similar type shoes. The main difference is that they cannot put the famous swoosh mark on it, but some other brands, like Double Flying Wheel.

    Nike and Double Flying Wheel, which do you think will sell if they are both priced the same? Nike is not in the business of manufacturing. They are quite happy to leave this to others. They are in the business of branding and selling and creating in the minds of the consumers a certain desire of wanting to own and use their products. By doing that, they have added much more value to just ordinary shoes. I do not believe, Sir, that a pair of Double Flying Wheel shoes should be any worse off in quality than your Nike.

    Why do people choose Nike? There are numerous reasons. And this is not a forum for us to go into these reasons. However, I will just dwell on one. I believe it has to do with the American brand name. There is somehow a certain cache in the minds of most consumers that if the product came from America, it must be of a good quality. For the same reason, we see in some advertisements that specific mention is often made of some consumer electronic items being from Japan.

    Sir, people I have spoken to tell me that Singapore is not America or Japan, and that it would be impossible for a boy from the backwaters to make it big in the city. I used to think that was the case. However, over the years, we come across numerous examples of how a small and provincial company, or even an individual, was able to take on the world and the world became his oyster. I cheered recently, when I read of how a local Singaporean boy was able to build a name for himself by selling his line of clothes in competition with the big fashion houses in Paris and New York; and is able to claim Nicole Kidman and the late Princess Diana as his clients. This boy fortunately came from

Column: 200

a family who is able to provide financial support for his dreams. Just think, if he did not have such an opportunity, he would probably be left selling his clothes in some run-down plaza in Orchard Road and the world would have passed him by without noticing him. And of course, would his clothes sell for the prices that he is now selling? Who would be the bigger loser in the long run? Singapore or the boy?

    We must pay more attention to brand building and brand management. The question is: how? Sir, in my previous speeches, I had made some suggestions on approaches. The first would be to strategically acquire or acquire substantial stakes to enable board representation in companies with very strong global brand names. In doing so, we not only acquire global companies that would help contribute to our total revenue but, if managed, would allow Singaporeans the ability to have a deeper and better understanding about the ways to international branding and marketing. Secondly, I note from the ERC Report that the proposal was made in respect of the setting up of an IP academy. While I welcome the establishment of such an academy, I am just concerned that, first, the approach taken by the academy may just be too academic and may not deal with the practical difficulties of managing intellectual properties. Secondly, the academy may just be another institution that is divorced from the reality of industry to be effective. Given the broad reach of the subject of intellectual property, I do hope that the academy would also devote much attention to the subject of brand building and brand management which, I would like to emphasise yet again, has not been given enough serious policy consideration that it deserves.

    At the risk of being simplistic, the world of business is very much about branding and selling. The better you are able to market and position your products and services, the better it is for you to cream off more fat for your bottom line. Everyone can manufacture a PC, it is only a question of unit cost production to stay competitive. But not everyone can create a

Column: 201

Dell or a Compaq brand name that sells around the world. In fact, most Dell computers are manufactured and shipped out to China; but who makes the big profits? The Chinese are fast recognising the importance of the game and will soon play catch up. We, in Singapore, still have the advantage of a name that the world trusts. We should capitalise on it or run the risk of being marginalised and lose the advantage that we have.

    Sir, I note the affirmation of our Government that manufacturing will continue to form an important underpinning of our economy. I would support the affirmation, provided that the manufacturing activities that we support would allow us to take advantage of our comparative advantage in relation to China and the other emerging economies. I would question whether or not we are better off leaving manufacturing to the others in most instances. The logic of the globalisation argument, as we are all aware, lies in the fact that labour and capital in an increasingly open world economy would always gravitate towards places that are most cost effective through sheer market forces. It could well be that, in many of our traditional industries, it may not be more efficient for Singapore to keep them. And I would be so bold as to predict that, in the next 10 years, many of our contract manufacturing facilities, including those that are presently found in the electronics sector, will eventually be relocated to China and other places.

    The way forward for Singapore is to consider its comparative advantage rather than its competitive advantage. Singapore's strength has always been its well-qualified English-speaking younger generation of the post-independence people and the quality of its public service. Additionally, the fact that it is small also means that it is nimble and could transform itself quite easily. Clearly, Singapore can be a leading centre for research and development and brand building and development. The overall total licensing market is estimated to be some $300 billion a year. If Singapore

Column: 202

cannot aspire to clinch even 5% of that share of the market, we might as well give up any pretensions about being a global industrial nation.

    If we are able, Sir, to develop strong global brand names, we would be able to build up a strong external economy, which will then give us much room to be inefficient in our domestic economy. For instance, we can earn enough more from our external economy to consider some form of subvention or fiscal incentive to encourage the employment of those who are structurally unemployed, especially the middle-aged workers. For them, we do not have to measure their efficiency against the workers from countries where cheap and untrained labour exists in abundance. The unit cost of these unskilled middle-aged Singaporean workers can then be matched more attractively with the support of our Government. This will provide employers here with a greater incentive to hire local employees as opposed to foreign employees.

    Sir, I know that the Government does not always welcome any suggestion of public subsidy, in whatever form. The conventional wisdom is that public subsidy robs the incentive from individuals to work and to improve themselves. While that may be true in general, there is no comparison when the argument is scrutinised more closely. It would be true to say that social benefits generally tend to make a person lazy and a sloth. However, what we are speaking here is to give a man back his dignity by giving him work that he would not otherwise be given, but for the intervention of the state. I know that such a policy may not satisfy in the longer term the requirement of economic efficiency. However, the point of the matter is that we do not need our domestic economy to be efficient all the time if our external economy is powering away strongly, such that it allows us this option. These structurally unemployed workers are still Singaporeans, and we will still have to carry them. Rather than give them handouts, which we have a duty to do if they are truly down, it may be better to subsidise them indirectly through employment.

Column: 203



    Sir, we are now at what most would consider the most significant crossroads of our nation's history. We are faced with having to make choices that would decide our people's fate. If we take the wrong path, the outcome could well be very different. The one salutary lesson that we have before us is New Zealand. Like Singapore, New Zealand was very much at the crossroads since the mid-80s. New Zealand also realised the need to restructure its economy and to raise its growth rate. It pointed to the need to boost training, promote entrepreneurship and facilitate new information technologies and strengthen economic fundamentals. These are clear mantras for growth which are easy to spout. Yet, the reality in the eyes of many, New Zealand has failed to achieve the results that it aims for. This is due to a whole host of factors, which included, among other things, the country backtracking on its labour reforms. Over the years, New Zealand's economy has receded to such an extent that it could not now even afford to maintain a combat wing for its air force. If you went to New Zealand today, you would not see many signs of physical wealth, which often in Asian context is measured by the number of Mercedes Benzes on the road.

    Singapore does not have to go the way of New Zealand. Unlike New Zealand, Singapore has a strong political will to see through the restructuring. We will not resile from taking politically tough decisions. Yet, political will may not be enough to see us through our present difficulties. We need to have clearer and more defined markers; which brings me now to the point about the ERC Report.

    While few would deny the logic of the proposals in the ERC Report, one could arguably say that the devil is in the detail as to how the Government is going to go about its task. The present Budget Statement has given us a broad indication of the steps that the Government is going to take. However, it has been said that we should perhaps have a sharper focus. I have earlier sought to define a more specific strategy of focusing on branding and intellectual knowledge as part of the

Column: 204

strategy of building a knowledge economy as a driver for Singapore's future. More, however, can be done. For instance, we can set clear goals for the next 10 to 15 years. It is not enough just to say that we will remake our economy and make it a pretty slogan. We ought to have specific measurable performance indicators, for instance, looking at how many companies we want to bring global. How many GLCs are going to privatise? How many startups we want to nurture, facilitating the growth and expansion of such businesses? This approach will give the exercise a stronger focus, enable us to offer more assistance where assistance is needed. Our strength is in our ability to work towards the long term, including investment, education and training. There is no reason why the ERC Report cannot aim for such concrete outcomes.

    This brings us back to the question that we have been grappling with over the years. How far should Government be involved in business? Leaving aside our usual gripes about the GLCs, I believe that there is still a role for Government in business. As in the past, our Government should continue to provide leadership in strategic areas where the private sector does not have the resources or the ability to venture into. Our Government should continue to divest its holdings in the private sector, businesses that can be handled by our businessmen. However, our Government should not cease to provide initiative in other areas where the leadership of which would help us with the crucial need to successfully build up our second economic wing. I do hope that, in venturing abroad, we would have learnt our lessons from the past and avoid making the same mistakes as before; not least of which is our Government's habit of getting civil servants with little or no commercial experience to drive such initiatives. What I have advocated for is a slight departure from the yellow pages rule. We should not be afraid of going into businesses that already exist locally. Rather, we should boldly enter into such areas and add value by creating world-class companies with world-class brand names out of opportunities that we are

Column: 205



    Sir, in all my years, I have never seen the mood on the ground to be so despairing and despondent. It is dispiriting for our people to wake up in the morning, to learn of hundreds of fellow Singaporeans being made redundant by the HDB or PSA. How many more will have to lose their jobs before our economy recovers, if it recovers? How many more middle-aged workers can we employ under the present climate? In this crisis, what should stand out is our ability to inspire the confidence of our people through our leadership. We should provide our people with a very clear roadmap on how we are going to navigate out of our present structural economic problems. Making broad statements about what we are going to do is not going to add any more confidence to the people. As I have said before, we should continue to provide sharper focus on our strategies. For me, I know where we should be heading. I would say once again that we should continue to build a strong external wing by investing in or acquiring world-class companies with world-class brand names, and leveraging on these companies to help us build our own global brand names. If we could do that, and do that successfully, we could then afford to have some inefficiency in our domestic economy by subsidising employment for Singaporeans who are not able to adapt to the employment demands of the new world economic order.

    Subject to the comments above, I support the Budget Statement.
