    Mr Chew Heng Ching (East Coast): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are many who have criticised the Budget for being "a non-event" and "uninspiring". In fact, one critique is on the removal of taxation on interest income from savings. One sarcastic remark often heard is that Singaporeans have no money to generate interest to be taxed now, given that economic conditions are so bad. Even for those who have money, interest rates

Column: 206

are so low that the impact of the relief is negligible. So, why introduce it now?

    Sir, like many other brickbats, these comments have missed some of the more salient benefits and measures announced in the Budget which will have a positive impact on the long-term health of the Singapore economy. Singaporeans do have good reasons to be concerned about their economic prospects and livelihoods, given the uncertainties that surround the world economy and the political environment today.

    However, they cannot and should not just leave the job of reinventing the economy to the Government, and assuming that the Government will save the day, or will hand out something to them should things worsen. There is a fundamental need in our Singaporean society to change our mindset to economic and social matters and indeed foster a greater spirit of self-reliance. And this is the biggest challenge before us.

    If we band together and change the way we see ourselves and do business, be more entrepreneurial in many aspects, the world is still our oyster. There are grounds to be optimistic and not miss the silver linings contained in the Budget 2003.

    Nevertheless, Singaporeans cannot just stick their heads in the sand like ostriches, and ignore the reality of the weak global economic environment confronting us today. We have been in a "soft spot" for over two years now and, unlike during the Asian financial crisis some five years ago, the US economy is also in bad shape. With a structurally weakening US dollar following budget and external deficits in the US, our ability to export ourselves out of any economic weaknesses may be further compromised. In addition, our reliance on MNCs to provide stable manufacturing jobs is fast being eroded by the cheaper competitors like India and China.

    In many respects, Sir, whilst we strive for value-added and highly skilled jobs to move up the value curve in job creation, or indeed to fulfill the EDB's vision to

Column: 207

transform Singapore into a "Global Entrepolis", we have to be very mindful of the fact that Singapore, with its high wage and land costs, will find it harder and harder to continue to be relevant economically. The Budget 2003's proposals on putting off the restoration of employers' CPF contributions, and its lack of incentives to further stimulate demand in the property market, may be difficult for Singaporeans to understand.

    Some measures which affect the pockets of the man-in-the-street are no doubt painful. They are, however, inevitable. Going forward, more radical measures to address these two cost components may still be required. And if we do not do that, when the next economic boom comes, Singapore may be left behind.

    Seen in this light, Sir, to me, the crucial platform that Budget 2003 has incorporated from the ERC's recommendations is its emphasis on entrepreneurship and the growth of Singapore companies. I am glad the Government has now recognised that we must reduce our over-reliance on MNCs, and actively promote entrepreneurship, self-reliance and innovation among Singapore companies.

    The appointment of my GRC colleague, Mr Raymond Lim, to head the entrepreneurship drive is a testament to the Government's commitment to ensure that Singaporeans can be lured out of their comfort zones, with incentives and some prodding on their backs. I am confident Mr Raymond Lim will do a good job and have as many of the ERC's recommendations on entrepreneurship implemented as quickly as possible. However, Sir, I do not envy him. He has a difficult task ahead.

    Unfortunately, I believe that to be successful in this initiative to boost entrepreneurship, no amount of safety nets and incentives alone will be enough to tempt Singaporeans out of their comfort zones. They are so used to the tried and tested path of pursuing higher education, jobs and stable careers. There has to be a complete overhaul of the different parts of Singaporean society, both in mindsets

Column: 208

and aspirations and, perhaps, a slow and gradual erosion of our kiasu and kiasi mentality.

    Sir, taking a leaf from Mr Sim Wong Hoo's Chaotic Thoughts from the Old Millennium, Singaporeans, by and large, suffer from "NUTS" or the "No U-Turn Syndrome". He points out that:

    "In the US, where there is no sign on the road, it means that you can make a U-turn. When the authorities do not want people to make U-turns, they put up signs to tell you not to make U-turns. In Singapore, it is the reverse. When there is no sign on the road, you are not allowed to make U-turns. When the authorities allow you to make U-turns, then they will put up a sign to give you that right."



    Sir, the bottomline is that both systems serve the same purpose, ie, to better manage traffic. They look similar, but the social repercussion is significant. The "no U-turn syndrome" has created a way of life for us that is based on rules. And, without rules, Singaporeans cannot perform. They are paralysed.

    Sir, we need to change our mindset. I fear that whilst our budget initiatives to boost entrepreneurship are good, we would not realise the intentions, if steps are not taken to also address this mindset across all Singaporean society. Civil servants, for instance, need to be prepared to make decisions that would be pro-business and pro-entrepreneurs. Civil servants must not assume that the businessmen are out to cheat the system and exploit loopholes. There is a need for a comprehensive review of internal policies that stymie business and entrepreneurs, so that the spirit of free enterprise can be enabled. I acknowledge that the Ministerial Committee on Services and the initiatives to streamline rules and regulations are already in place. However, Sir, more needs to be done at a faster pace.

    Sir, I have long pointed out in this House that to effectively change the bureaucracy, we would need to enable more cross-overs of private sector talents into the civil service - perhaps, even as high as the Permanent Secretary level. After all, if the status quo continues, it could be self-perpetuating and not be conducive and

Column: 209

responsive to change. Those from the private sector surely would be able to bring their perspective, from being on the other side of the table, to good and immediate use, rather than trying to get civil servants with long-standing practices to try to stand in the shoes of the private sector - a much more onerous task. I suggest that the Government seriously look at employing more private sector talents into key positions within the civil service, in the same way that we are now seeing more Ministers in Cabinet who are from the private sector.

    Sir, there is also a need for more attention to be paid to our younger workers and students in secondary and tertiary education. This generation should not be told to achieve greater academic qualifications and skills upgrades alone. It is precisely this motivation that has made many Singaporeans kiasu. The higher the educational certificate, or the more paper qualifications achieved, the higher the opportunity costs in leaving the comfort zone from the rule-based path of JC, university, stable job and career growth.

    I note the disappointment aired by a recent graduate to the Straits Times' Forum Page last week on not being able to land a job after getting his university qualifications. This is in stark contrast to the winner of Her World's Young Woman Entrepreneur Award, Elim Chew, who graduated from the school of hard knocks, at the lower end of her "O" level cohort, and many business failures. Persevering and with drive, she now runs a business of more than $10 million turnover per year. We would need to train students to inculcate in them the mindset of risk-taking and self-reliance, so that the future economy in Singapore can be bottom-up, broad-based with depth and breadth of enterprise.

    Sir, take another example of mindset change. It was recently reported that the School of Sports Excellence to be set up has a criterion to take in only students who are from the Express stream. Why do we restrict ourselves to this rule? True,

Column: 210

some of our top sportsmen have been strong academically as well, but there are many more equally successful, such as Fandi Ahmad and Remy Ong. Our Asian Games bowling champion, Remy Ong, for instance, has even set up his own business. They are both not from the Express stream. There must be a sea change in our thinking across-the-board, so that flexibility in approach, daring to try, and risk taking, can permeate throughout our society.

    Sir, another measure that many would like to see would be the freeing up of the portion of CPF beyond the Minimum Sum, for use as business investment. There are some who have substantial savings in their CPF. These individuals are likely to be successful in their career, and have substantial private savings and investments, and insurance or pension plans of their own. Having a significant portion of their funds locked up in CPF would be a disadvantage, should we want to encourage entrepreneurship among the more able in our society.

    I would therefore like to suggest that perhaps a means test, say, for an individual having $X of private investment/pension set aside already, be adopted to allow for the withdrawal of CPF for business investment. Entrepreneurial activity should not be capped on the basic assumption that Singaporeans cannot think and plan for themselves, and need to lock up funds in their CPF. Some can and should be given the leeway to expand the depth of enterprise in our economy.

    Finally, Sir, I speak for many Singaporeans in expressing our concern about the state of our economy. True, pump-priming does not work that well in Singapore, as 80 cents of a dollar pumped in is leaked out in our highly open economy. The conditions in the labour market in the private sector are still difficult, with pay cuts, wage freezes and retrenchments seen. And this is now seen in the public sector, such as HDB and PSA Corp.

    Still, Sir, it is not all doom and gloom. Many have alluded to the problems facing Singapore today as akin to Japan after the

Column: 211

twin bubbles in their property and stock markets burst in 1992. True, we are a smaller nation and would find riding the rough tides of economic ocean tougher at times. However, in our smaller size lies our flexibility to adapt and change. As long as Singaporeans continue to pull together to make the painful sacrifices, our long-term economic future is in good hands. Indeed, unlike Japan, it is fortunate that Singaporeans have chosen wisely to have good continuous stable Government, which is able to implement essential policies for the long-term good of Singaporeans, even if it involves some pain in the near term. We should be proud of that, stand tall against the challenges we face, and I am confident that, with continued good Government in place, we will rise to the occasion again.

    Sir, I support the Budget Statement delivered by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance.

    Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to take part in this Budget debate.

    This year's Budget contains a clear and unequivocal message for workers. There has been a significant shift in the labour market, and this has vast implications on workers. Although manufacturing remains one of the two key engines of our economy, it is no longer the largest provider of jobs. Most of the jobs are found in the services sector, but even this sector is not spared. Some jobs have shifted out of the services sector to lower cost locations. The public sector, which has undergone a lot of changes over the last few years, is also no longer a safe haven. In a nutshell, the employment market has drastically changed, and painful adjustments have to be made.

    Sir, we can see these changes that are taking place and know and understand why they are happening. Jobs are less permanent now, and shorter-term, compared to the past, and no one can expect to retire in his first job any more. But, at the same time, we must also understand that workers have families and commitments which are regular, permanent and

Column: 212

long-term. Hence, they need income stability and job security.

    How do we ensure that we continue to maintain a flexible job market but at the same time do not cause such huge fluctuations in our workers' lives as to destabilise families and our society? Can we achieve these twin objectives of a flexible labour market, which means that more of the ups and downs would have to be borne by workers, as against their need for balance and stability? Ms Chua Mui Hoong, in her article in the Straits Times dated 8th March 2003, argued that people should stop lamenting about job losses and instead should focus on how to manage job shifts. While I agree with her on this and the many other good points which she had made, I am a bit concerned about one point which she had raised. She had argued that the employment relationship should be treated as a purely commercial contract, and one should not look beyond that. If we accept this argument, I fear that one day, we will even have to do away with core legislation which protects workers' interest and welfare, such as the Employment Act or the Workmen's Compensation Act, as the argument would then be that workers should take care of these needs through individual contract negotiations. Is this a desirable development from our society's point of view? I clearly submit that it is not, as the fact remains that there are inequalities in the labour market which cannot be completely removed by adopting a strictly commercial approach. Hence, some form of legislation and system has to be put in place to ensure fairness and to balance the interest between enterprises and workers. I would argue, Sir, that this approach is good, not only for individuals and families, but also for the economy and for employers too. Workers who are more stable and secure can contribute more effectively and efficiently to the company and our economy.

    Sir, I want to make one point clear though. I am not suggesting that we should become even more protectionist. But I am arguing on the need for a balance. I also wish to make the point that

Column: 213

as we review and refine the present structure that is in place in order to achieve labour market flexibility, we also need to update and refine the existing system that is in place to protect workers' welfare.

    A key refinement that is sorely needed is clearly portability of core benefits. Currently, other than the CPF, the other employment benefits are rigid in two ways. They are mostly tied to workers' present job and are not movable. Secondly, they also depend on a person's length of service. A case in point is the medical benefits, which are important to workers as healthcare cost is a grave concern for many. But as the Finance Minister correctly pointed out, once a worker moves out of a job, he loses the benefit. For older workers, this is particularly hard as employers do not want to hire them because of concerns over higher medical costs.

    Sir, I am very happy that the Government has accepted the ERC's recommendation on portable medical benefits and decided to raise the tax exemption limit for additional Medisave contributions from private sector employees from 1% of an employee's monthly salary at present to a lump sum of $1,500 per employee per year. But, Sir, I would like to request that the Government consider two refinements. First, I would like to ask that the Government consider providing incentives for older workers to move into the portable medical benefits scheme. This is important, as they would otherwise not find the scheme attractive enough, as the portable medical benefits scheme is essentially a savings scheme and the earlier you come on board the scheme, the better. Hence, for older workers, because they have fewer number of years to work before retirement, they may find the scheme less attractive. Having any support from the Government will be very helpful in terms of extra premiums or other incentives.

    Another possibility is for the Government to consider providing different

Column: 214

scales of benefits for tax exemption for workers of different age groups. For example, older workers can be given a higher tax exemption instead of a blanket exemption of $1,500 for everyone.

    Secondly, I would also like to ask the Government to consider pegging the additional 1% contribution into the Medisave account to the median wage of our workers. This would ensure that lower income workers have a basic floor. Otherwise, the contribution that they receive will not be meaningful enough to encourage them to adopt the portable medical benefits scheme and would not provide effective protection. Pegging the 1% contribution to the median wage is a fair and reasonable suggestion. So, I would like to ask the Minister to seriously consider this proposal.

    Sir, along the line which I have argued earlier on the need for refinements to our existing system to ensure a balance between flexibility and protection, it is important that we continue to strengthen our social safety net. As the economy restructures and jobs are shared, there is a need to ensure that workers get some form of compensation to tide them over their unemployment period. While news reports are full of high profile cases, like the PSA and HDB where some have lamented that the benefits are generous, there are cases where workers are not paid when the companies retrench or wind up. While there is flexibility for employers to shed workers, we also have to ensure that employers exercise this right fairly and in a responsible manner. So, I call upon the Government to monitor the retrenchment situation closely to ensure that employers comply with the tripartite guidelines when dealing with excess manpower and ensure that workers are paid retrenchment benefits when they are retrenched. Under the guidelines, employers are required to consider implementing a shorter workweek and other measures for reducing costs before resorting to retrenchments. But there is no means of ensuring that employees comply with these.

    There are two measures which I hope to seek a response from the Government.

Column: 215

One possibility of further strengthening our social safety net is the setting up of a fund which could be used to pay some benefits to workers who are retrenched. I know that, in the past, this idea had been shot down. It had not been well-received but I think there is some need now for us to rethink about this issue. A key issue here is, of course, financing. But I would like to suggest also that when a review of the CPF is conducted, the Government could consider setting aside a portion of the CPF into this fund. Also, instead of giving out shares or topping up the Medisave, perhaps the Government could consider contributing into this fund.

    Sir, I do not have ready answers on this. But this is an issue that we need to discuss and forge a consensus on how to move ahead. As the long-term unemployment rate will remain high with structural unemployment complicating the issue, there is clearly a need to engage in further discussions on this. In order to prevent this fund from becoming a disincentive to work, there can be conditions attached, such as the maximum that can be withdrawn and the need for the retrenched worker to make serious efforts to find a job. Financing, as I said, is a key issue, but I am quite confident that if we can continue to discuss, we may be able to forge a consensus.

    On the issue of foreign workers, Sir, I agree that there must be flexibility. I accept the argument that there is no way that the 600,000 foreign workers can be replaced by the 80,000 Singaporeans who are unemployed. To send back even 10% of these foreign workers will significantly impact on our economy and cause loss of jobs among Singaporeans if companies pull out due to a shortage of labour or because of the lack of skilled workers. But at the same time, I feel that there is a need for balance and for the Government to monitor this issue more closely. The quotas were fixed during periods when unemployment amongst Singaporeans was lower. But with the current high unemployment rate and the projected long-term unemployment rate of up to 5%, these quotas may not be sustainable. Hence, I call upon the Government to

Column: 216

review the foreign worker quota more frequently and at shorter intervals, depending on the economic and employment situation, to ensure that Singaporeans are not disadvantaged.

    Sir, a core element of ensuring that there is a balance between flexibility and protection is workers' training and skills upgrading. I strongly support the formation of a statutory board to undertake the Continuing Education and Training and job assistance programmes. This is an important milestone in our effort to upgrade workers' skills. The current measures on job assistance were developed primarily over the last few years, arising out of the economic downturn. However, structural unemployment will be a long-term phenomenon. Hence, a more coordinated and more encompassing approach is needed in dealing with workers' training and job placement.

    There is certainly a need to establish a closer nexus between training and job placement. But, on the other hand, some flexibility is necessary. If a worker is trained only if he can be placed in a job, this would also act as a disincentive to training. I want to applaud the Government for setting aside $500 million for the Lifelong Learning Fund and another $37 million for skills upgrading efforts. Singapore's huge investment in education and skills training is the envy of many countries. Many countries aspire to educate and reskill their workers as we do. Our efforts have been cited in many international publications, such as ILO's or the United Nations' publications, but few countries could come close to what we have done in terms of our heavy investment in our people.

    The real challenge in reskilling our workforce is how to ensure that those who really need the training attend training courses. Based on anecdotal evidence in the Malay community, for instance, my sense is that, in terms of percentage, the better qualified ones are those who are more likely to undergo training. We should have a more in-depth understanding and analysis of the training profile of our workers so that we could

Column: 217

have a more targeted and focused approach in our training efforts. I hope that the statutory board charged with Continuing Education and Training would be able to deal with this issue in a more focused and coordinated way.

    Sir, another aspect of balance which is necessary, in my view, is to look at how to help employees balance work and family. For years, we have been trying to increase the birthrate. But we have made very little progress. Last year, despite all the incentives given to families to have more children, we had the lowest birthrate in 14 years. The underlying reason is clearly the inability of many dual-income families to cope with the increasing demands of work and family. Many women today work not for aesthetic reasons or for self-fulfillment but because they have to. Women's income constitutes a significant percentage of the total family income. Many companies have found that helping their employees balance work and family means greater job satisfaction, less turnover and higher productivity.

    So, I call upon the Government, Sir, to give a stronger push to initiatives to promote work and family balance. As the issues affecting the family is multi-faceted, it may be timely to consider setting up a National Family Council, akin to the National Youth Council, to take care of all matters pertaining to the family. The National Family Council can act as the coordinating body, as well as the body to champion all matters pertaining to family.

    I would also like to request the Government to consider increasing the subsidy for parents who put their children in childcare centres. The last time that the subsidy was increased was some years ago when it was fixed at $150. Since then, childcare fees have gone up but the subsidy has not been reviewed.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I also call upon the Government to pay special attention to the plight of older workers. Ageism is alive and well and employers continue to discriminate against older workers

Column: 218

who are considered unproductive, slower and not adaptable or trainable. Such stereotypes are not only demeaning but also untrue. I have met many older workers who are unhappy that despite the efforts to upgrade and change mindsets, employers continue to discriminate against them. We need to highlight and recognise best practices among employers. The Ministry of Manpower can perhaps work out a scheme to recognise efforts of employers who have successfully integrated their older workers in their workforce.

    Sir, let me move on to the public sector. I must say that there are a lot of anxieties when the Budget Statement mentioned that there would be a review of public sector's services with the possibility of privatising some of these services. There are two points which I would like to make. First, in line with our strong tripartite tradition, I would like to urge the relevant Ministries and statutory boards to consult and involve the unions before restructurings are carried out, so that workers' concerns can be addressed and the restructurings can be properly carried out. In this regard, I must commend the HDB management for involving the union and the extensive consultations that they had with the union and the workers before the restructuring.

    Sir, managing change effectively is critical to ensure that we do not end up with a demoralised public sector and to ensure that the outcomes which are desired are actually achieved. Secondly, Sir, I hope that the Government will put in place a system to monitor the quality and delivery of the services which have been hived off or may be hived off to the private sector to ensure that the same level of quality in good service is maintained. A key reason why there is strong opposition to privatisation of public sector services in many countries is because after privatisation, people find that the cost of the services either went up or the quality was affected. Hence, we need to ensure that whilst the objective of outsourcing services that can now be provided by the public sector to the private sector is cost, this should not result in a lower or more costly service

Column: 219



    Sir, I agree with Mr Leong Horn Kee that there are concerns among the older workers, whether they have enough savings in their CPF. I also agree with Mr Inderjit Singh that there is a need to further promote the monthly variable component. I strongly support the Deputy Prime Minister's call that employers should pass on part of the cost-savings to deserving workers through the variable component of wages.

    During these difficult times, it is important that we continue to maintain the trust and confidence of workers. If companies that are still doing well do not reward workers, or try to exploit the current economic downturn, then I am afraid that irreparable damage will be done, and people will be less willing to accept change or to make sacrifices. It is also important that while we ask workers to tighten their belts and accept harsh measures for their own future, the Government continues to ensure that the cost of living does not escalate. If wages do not increase, or the pace of increase is very moderate, but healthcare, housing, transport or other cost increase, then this would cause hardship and affect workers' standard of living. Hence, I urge all service providers, whether public or private, to heed people's anxieties and concerns and do not indiscriminately increase their charges.

    Sir, I also call upon the Government to continue to monitor the situation of low income Singaporeans. This is to ensure that they receive the assistance that they need. There are help schemes that are already in place but we need to review these schemes from time to time, to ensure that they are adequate and are accessible to those who are really in need.

    In conclusion, Sir, how would I describe this year's Budget? To me, this year's Budget can be summed up in three words - pro-growth, pro-job and pro-workers. This is not an assessment that everyone would agree with. Some had said that this is a pro-business and pro-employer Budget. They pointed to the many incentives given to businesses, compared to some of the painful measures for workers. So, as a

Column: 220

unionist, why am I arguing that this Budget is pro-worker? Mr Speaker, Sir, this is because we, in the labour movement, understand the realities down the ground. Ask any worker today and he will tell you that his major concern is about employment. Those who are employed are worried that they will lose their jobs. Those without jobs are worried about how fast they would secure another one. After the retrenchments in PSA and the restructuring in HDB, many wait anxiously and watch out for signs that will tell them whether their company is next on the line. There is an air of uncertainty and general anxiety in the atmosphere.

    Sir, having spent more than two decades in the labour movement, I must say that this is the most challenging period that I have experienced. In such a climate, any measures that will help to preserve jobs or to delay retrenchments are welcomed. Any measures that tell us how new investments will be drawn in and new jobs created are welcomed. Will the measures announced in this Budget guarantee that no jobs are lost? Will it guarantee that new jobs will be created to soak up new entrants to the labour market and the retrenched? Will it guarantee that older workers will continue to be employed? The reality is that no one can guarantee anything, as there are just too many imponderables. But then we, in the labour movement, ask ourselves whether we would be worse off or better off without these measures. Sir, if we stick steadfastly to old paradigms and rules, will it help the workers or make their situation worse? How should we champion and articulate workers' interest? Does championing workers' interest mean that we have to take the popular line and shout slogans or do we adopt a more responsible attitude, analyse issues, think out the strategies and work out the programmes to help our workers? We in the labour movement have decided to cut the rhetoric, roll up our sleeves and get down to work.

    Singapore's progress is in no small measure due to this responsible part that we have played in protecting workers' interest. After much soul searching, we

Column: 221

agree that, difficult though some of these ERC measures may be, they are necessary for the short-term as well as to protect the long-term interest of workers. At least with these measures we now stand more than a fighting chance to make a break and to recover strongly. If we had stuck to our guns, we may not even have that fighting chance. Take the case of the 2-year CPF deferment. Sir, I must tell you that there was also a lot of soul searching on our part. Some would have preferred to wait and have it assessed on a yearly basis. But at the end of the day, many of us are persuaded that we are not dealing with normal times. We are dealing with unusual times. And unusual times require unusual measures, unusual ways of doing things and unusual sacrifices.

    Sir, there are so many threats and challenges that Singapore is faced with. It is as if our entire resolve as a nation is being tested. I must say that we have kept the flag flying high. It has not been easy to get people to think and see the long-term. Sometimes, I think that there is a perennial disconnect between the Government's long-term plans and visions and desire for people to think long-term and people's concern over their short-term needs. The challenge for Singapore really is how to bridge this perception gap so that we have more people thinking on the same wave-length. At the end of the day, Sir, what will hold us together as a people and enable us to overcome these huge challenges that we are now faced with is the trust and confidence that people have in the Government. This trust and confidence is not something that is developed by chance or that came about overnight. It arose because the Government has repeatedly kept faith with the people and delivered on its promises. I am confident that a new partnership is now developing between the Government and the people. Trust and confidence is still a key consideration, but in this new partnership it also requires greater ownership and responsibility on the part of all Singaporeans.

    On this note, Sir, I support the Budget.

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun (Hong Kah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am happy to note that the Finance Minister in his 2003 Budget has taken into account many of the points made by the ERC and its various sub-committees. The ERC Report highlights the problems Singapore faces in the transition towards a full-fledged first world economy. Its recommendations will serve us well in the future as we strive to find our place in the new knowledge era. I would like to congratulate members of the ERC and its sub-committees for a job well done.

    The current gloomy scenario is a good time to take stock, consolidate and plan for the future. However, we must not confuse ourselves between the effects of the current downturn and the effects of long-term change, which is brought about by globalisation, the new economy and Singapore's progress into the premier economic league. The ERC should be commended for addressing both the short-term and long-term problems. Today, I would like to comment on the issues of Singapore's competitiveness and helping dislocated Singaporeans to remain employed.

    First, on competitiveness. I believe that Government can and should help Singapore businesses, be they domestic or international, to be competitive. We can do it by taking the Singapore Inc approach. By "Singapore Inc", I mean Government and businesses consider each other as partners to promote a flourishing economy. There is greater urgency for this now as we compete as a nation in a globalised environment. Government agencies must therefore seek ways to facilitate businesses and encourage entrepreneurship by removing obstacles and help the implementation of new and novel ideas. This will require a new mindset on the part of the Government, in that the Government, together with civil servants must stand on the side of businesses to help them survive and prosper.

    I am glad that Minister of State, Raymond Lim, has recognised the need

Column: 223

for this new mindset in his speech earlier, and Mr Inderjit Singh has also spoken on this. It is not unlike the role of EDB helping MNCs to set up their businesses in Singapore. Likewise, SPRING Singapore, and indeed all Government agencies should go all out to help businesses in their thoughts and actions, be more market-friendly, and when an application goes against existing rules and regulations, find ways to justify the applications, without making the rules meaningless. Let me give one or two simple real-life examples to illustrate my point.

    A grassroots leader of mine operates an eating house along Race Course Lane in the central area. The property next to his has an extension jutting out from the main facade. As a good businessman, my grassroots leader put up his eating house sign above his gate away from his facade, but in line with his next door extension, so that the visibility of the sign would not be obstructed and his business would not be affected. Lo and behold, he was asked to remove the sign by the authority because advertisement rules in the central area require the sign to be flushed with the property facade. He appealed but was rejected. I found this unacceptable and so I appealed on his behalf to the Minister, arguing that if the next door extension had been allowed, and had already changed the facade of the original row of properties, why should the authority insist that the eating house sign must be flushed with its own facade? Fortunately, the Minister agreed and the appeal was granted. But what if I had not appealed? The problem should therefore not have remained unresolved in the first place. This will be the case if the relevant Government officer believes that he also has a duty to assist businesses.

    Let me give Members another example. A construction company recently bought over a cement plant to produce cement for its own use. One way to make its cement competitive compared to imported cement is to lower the cost of importing the raw material. The company found that if it is allowed to unload the raw material at the existing Government jetty, which is being used now for

Column: 224

unloading of sand and granite, it can save substantially on import cost, as opposed to unloading the material at Jurong Port. The company applied for permission to do it on the grounds that the physical form of the raw material to be imported is similar to sand and granite. In addition, if the cement plant survives, it will continue to provide jobs and utilise a substantial amount of electric power. The authority, however, rejected its application. One official actually told the company that it should just import the cement instead of producing it in Singapore.

    Mr Sim Wong Hoo, therefore, hit the nail on its head when, according to his book "Chaotic Thoughts From The Old Millennium", he told his customer service officers that they were in fact the customers' advocates and they had to be fighting with him for their customers' interest rather than the other way round. I believe civil servants must adopt the same attitude. They must realise that they work for Singapore, as part of Singapore Inc, and that the businesses which they deal with are their allies, as well as their customers, and not an adversary to be challenged at every opportunity. It is commonly perceived that when a civil servant is faced with an application for a new business activity, which does not conform with some existing rule or policy, his gut reaction will be to simply reject the application. This is what Minister of State Raymond Lim earlier referred to as the default "No" button. The civil servant will, at best, and in line with our campaign for a gracious society, find a nice way to write the rejection letter. However, it does not solve the problem of the business applicant and, worse, if the applicant has come with a brilliant, revolutionary idea which can benefit Singapore.

    So what should civil servants do? First and foremost, if it has not already happened, the attitude of just following the rules has got to change. Yes, we must follow rules, regulations, policies and guidelines. They are needed for good order. However, they must not be obeyed blindly. When an application from a business with a new idea comes along, civil servants ought to try to help it obtain

Column: 225

the approvals it needs. In the new economy, and if Singapore is to remain competitive, that should be their duty. This is how they can become the "customer's advocates".

    If the application cannot be approved due to some rule or policy, the civil servants should help the applicant find a way around the problem. If the case is good enough and is beyond his authority to approve, he should bring it up to his bosses. He should never wait for the applicant, who is his customer, to appeal to the "higher authorities". Being the advocate, he should initiate the appeal on his "customer's" behalf.

    Secondly, in our civil service system, his immediate superior should welcome such initiative instead of finding it bothersome. Indeed, the immediate superior should now, in turn, become the customer's advocate to help the applicant obtain his approval. If a satisfactory decision still cannot be made, the matter should progress further up the civil service hierarchy. As far as possible, it should not be a matter that needs to be brought up at a meet-the-people session and be resolved by MPs writing to the Minister.

    In this way, all avenues can be explored before turning down business applications with sufficiently good ideas. New ideas do not come about easily. Surely, we must give them due consideration before tossing them into the bin, just because of some old rule.

    If such due process is given before rejecting applications, the entrepreneur will at least be encouraged by the experience. He will be willing to try again in future because he can see that the Government and civil servants are on his side, and not another obstacle to be surmounted. Mr Speaker, Sir, this is one way we can encourage more entrepreneurship in Singapore.

    Another important issue affecting competitiveness is land. Members have spoken about it. Land cost is an important

Column: 226

factor of production. I am glad that the ERC has recommended that our industrial and commercial land be priced competitively in relation with competing nations. In order to achieve this, land should not be priced according to alternative use but in accordance with its direct industry use. Being the largest land owner, the Government can exert a great influence over land cost.

    While there is a need to lower land cost generally, I understand that there is also a dilemma. If land prices fall too drastically, existing land owners and lessees will be hard hit. Our financial system may be affected thus worsening our already fragile economy. However, while caution is prudent, I urge the Government not to "do nothing" or too little since land cost is one major factor affecting our competitiveness.

    Two measures announced by DPM during his Budget 2003 speech are for a property tax rebate and rental rebates. Unfortunately, these measures are only for six months. I find this too cautious and feel that we can be far more generous. Let me explain.

    DPM has justified that the freeze in the restoration of the employer's CPF contribution rates for a further two years is to give certainty to the employers, MNCs and investors about the CPF issue. It is intended to send a strong signal that we are serious in solving our problems and that we are determined to keep our business cost competitive. This is the sacrifice our workers are asked to make. But when it comes to Government rebates, I am puzzled that the Government is only prepared to give six months. Should not the Government also make the same commitment of two years on land and other costs and send an equally strong signal to investors?

    The property tax rebate and the extension of rental rebates, together with the reduction of foreign worker levy and the reduction of diesel tax, etc, should also be given over a period of the same two years, instead of only six months. This will certainly send an equally strong signal to

Column: 227

our workers. Yes, with the war looming and economic uncertainties reaching an unprecedented height, perhaps the Government should be even bolder and increase the quantum of the property tax and rental rebates given.

    The longer period of two years is not as "reckless" as it seems. If the economy recovers, the Government will have more tax income and can well afford it. If not, then these rebates and reduction are certainly needed to lower business cost. Heads, we win; tails, we also win - what could be better?

    Another threat we face is the hollowing out of some of our industries and the loss of jobs. The ERC has reported that we have sufficient industrial land. Therefore, we should start to consider pricing land according to industry use to hold on to even the lower-tech industries through competitive land prices, and dissuade them from migrating to low cost countries. We need to do this in order to provide continued employment for Singaporeans who find it difficult to re-skill. It is better to do this than to give them social assistance. Perhaps in order to limit any undesirable effects, this measure can be strictly targeted. We can start by putting aside only a small portion of our JTC land bank for this purpose. This is better than leaving our land vacant when these lower-tech companies migrate.

    Sir, capital is another important factor. I agree with the Government on various measures to encourage the people to keep their capital or money in Singapore. Lower direct taxes will allow for capital regeneration. The stable Singapore dollar policy is also beneficial to capital inflows. Elimination of taxes on profits repatriated from abroad will also encourage more Singaporeans to bring back much needed money from their overseas operations and help lift the domestic economy. Abolishing taxes on interest earned from deposits in Singapore will also encourage money to remain here.

    The capital allowances for all capital items will also be beneficial to encourage risk-taking. I also urge the Government to

Column: 228

allow losses from an overseas subsidiary to be consolidated at the group level for taxation purposes. This measure will encourage our companies to go overseas and globalise.

    There may be some concern of abuse. However, the Government is already aware of this possibility and I am sure appropriate measures, like capping the quantum of losses allowable for group tax relief, or a registration or monitoring system, can be instituted to prevent this.

    Sir, the new knowledge economy will throw up one undesirable effect, ie, structural unemployment. There will be workers who will find it too difficult to retrain and reskill, either due to their age or other factors. As a modern society, we must provide some assistance to such people, not only in the form of a pure monetary handout, but also meaningful work so that their self-esteem does not suffer. My earlier suggestion on reserving some cheap land for lower-tech industries will help. However, more can be done.

    I am sure Members will agree that financial help which is tied to the performance of some meaningful work is far superior to a pure handout, like ERS shares. Such work schemes may be difficult to implement due to the concern that some unscrupulous people may abuse it. Nevertheless, we should not be swayed from the higher intent and should find ways to overcome these difficulties.

    It is a good idea to counter structural unemployment by using the concept of "negative income tax". This measure is better, more meaningful and more effective than the "handouts" given since the negative income tax is associated with job creation. The Government already provides subsidies for various training and apprenticeship schemes. In general, this can be further extended more widely and for longer periods, if necessary.

    For older workers, I would like to urge the Government to consider subsidising part of their CPF payments, instead of simply instituting a cut in the contribution rates. This achieves the intention of

Column: 229

lowering costs for employers and will also protect the workers' retirement nest-egg from shrinkage. The amount of Government expenditure needed is small compared to the total expenditure. The money spent here is better spent, more targeted, than simply handing out shares or money across the board.

    Further, I would like the Government to consider instituting a "paid" community or social work scheme. The benefits of this are two-fold: the old, chronically sick, underprivileged and the community will gain from the services provided and improve their quality of life; and the longer-term unemployed will find some meaningful work to do for some pocket money. The newspapers reported that one Town Council is already doing this in a limited way by "employing" those out of work to do checks and inspections on common facilities so that a better level of maintenance can be achieved. The Government can provide some money for this and other schemes to be instituted and expanded. These can include a social visitor scheme for the old and the sick who are alone at home, or schemes such as neighbourhood watch, etc.

    In the social visitor scheme, our unemployed can be trained to provide visits to the old, infirm or sick. These are the underprivileged who would normally be left alone at home, unable to move around easily, and need help with simple errands or maybe simply a friend to talk to. We can certainly improve the quality of life for such unfortunate people by taking care of their basic needs and, at the same time, provide some useful work for those that are unemployed.

    In the neighbourhood watch scheme, an allowance can be paid to those who need a job for their role in providing some neighbourhood watch service. This could include neighbourhood patrols or even simply stationing themselves in key areas to deter petty criminals and other offenders. In difficult times like this, there is a tendency for such crimes to increase and this will be a good counter measure.

Column: 230



    Finally, Sir, I would like to close with a comment on the budget deficit. I do realise that some of my earlier recommendations need to be funded. DPM has already taken pains to point out that the FY 2003 Budget will be the third consecutive year of budget deficits. However, many have fed back that the Budget could have been more generous. The projected deficit is $900 million. But during better years, we achieved surpluses of around $4-$5 billion a year. Why can the Government not contemplate a deficit nearer such a level in what is notably a very trying and uncertain time? The war on Iraq seems inevitable. It may happen within days. The Prime Minister has advised Singaporeans to expect tougher times ahead in the next few months. The outcome of the war is an unknown. What if it is an unfavourable one affecting adversely the political and economic environment of the world over a longer period of time? Do we have the assurance of the Government to introduce another off-Budget package of measures to help Singaporeans?

    In the light of what I have said, I support the Budget. However, I hope that DPM will give due consideration to my suggestions. And I hope he will also give a commitment to provide further generous off-Budget measures to give the economy a much needed boost should the worst in the Iraq crisis come about.

    The Government is making fundamental changes to promote entrepreneurship. This is encouraging and I am confident

with these changes, we are making progressive steps in the right direction.

    Mr Loh Meng See (Jalan Besar): Sir, it is a tradition for me to attend the gathering of Trade and Merchants Associations on the first day of Chinese New Year. I have been doing this since becoming an MP. What struck me in this year's annual get-together was the depressing mood - a sense of hopelessness and defeatism that the situation in Singapore is no longer salvageable. Column: 235
